text: ਸੋ ਟਿਕਾ ਸੋ ਬੈਹਣਾ ਸੋਈ ਦੀਬਾਣੁ ॥

translation.text: The same mark on the forehead, the same throne, and the same Royal Court.

transliteration.text: sō tikā sō baihanā sōī dībān .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਪਿਯੂ ਦਾਦੇ ਜੇਵਿਹਾ ਪੋਤਾ ਪਰਵਾਣੁ ॥

translation.text: Just like the father and grandfather, the son is approved.

transliteration.text: piyū dādē jēvihā pōtā paravān .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਜਿਨਿ ਬਾਸਕੁ ਨੇਤ੍ਰੈ ਘਤਿਆ ਕਰਿ ਨੇਹੀ ਤਾਣੁ ॥ ਜਿਨਿ ਸਮੁੰਦੁ ਵਿਰੋਲਿਆ ਕਰਿ ਮੇਰੁ ਮਧਾਣੁ ॥

translation.text: He took the thousand-headed serpent as his churning string, and with the force of devotional love, he churned the ocean of the world with his churning stick, the Sumayr mountain.

transliteration.text: jin bāsak nētrai ghatiā kar nēhī tān . jin samund virōliā kar mēr madhān .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਚਉਦਹ ਰਤਨ ਨਿਕਾਲਿਅਨੁ ਕੀਤੋਨੁ ਚਾਨਾਣੁ ॥

translation.text: He extracted the fourteen jewels, and brought forth the Divine Light.

transliteration.text: chaudah ratan nikālian kītōn chānān .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਘੋੜਾ ਕੀਤੋ ਸਹਜ ਦਾ ਜਤੁ ਕੀਓ ਪਲਾਣੁ ॥

translation.text: He made intuition his horse, and chastity his saddle.

transliteration.text: ghōrā kītō sahaj dā jat kīō palān .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਧਣਖੁ ਚੜਾਇਓ ਸਤ ਦਾ ਜਸ ਹੰਦਾ ਬਾਣੁ ॥

translation.text: He placed the arrow of the Lord's Praise in the bow of Truth.

transliteration.text: dhanakh charāiō sat dā jas handā bān .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਕਲਿ ਵਿਚਿ ਧੂ ਅੰਧਾਰੁ ਸਾ ਚੜਿਆ ਰੈ ਭਾਣੁ ॥

translation.text: In this Dark Age of Kali Yuga, there was only pitch darkness. Then, He rose like the sun to illuminate the darkness.

transliteration.text: kal vich dhū andhār sā chariā rai bhān .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਸਤਹੁ ਖੇਤੁ ਜਮਾਇਓ ਸਤਹੁ ਛਾਵਾਣੁ ॥

translation.text: He farms the field of Truth, and spreads out the canopy of Truth.

transliteration.text: satah khēt jamāiō satah shāvān .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਨਿਤ ਰਸੋਈ ਤੇਰੀਐ ਘਿਉ ਮੈਦਾ ਖਾਣੁ ॥

translation.text: Your kitchen always has ghee and flour to eat.

transliteration.text: nit rasōī tērīai ghiu maidā khān .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਚਾਰੇ ਕੁੰਡਾਂ ਸੁਝੀਓਸੁ ਮਨ ਮਹਿ ਸਬਦੁ ਪਰਵਾਣੁ ॥

translation.text: You understand the four corners of the universe; in your mind, the Word of the Shabad is approved and supreme.

transliteration.text: chārē kundānh sujhīōs man mah sabad paravān .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਆਵਾ ਗਉਣੁ ਨਿਵਾਰਿਓ ਕਰਿ ਨਦਰਿ ਨੀਸਾਣੁ ॥

translation.text: You eliminate the comings and goings of reincarnation, and bestow the insignia of Your Glance of Grace.

transliteration.text: āvā gaun nivāriō kar nadar nīsān .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਅਉਤਰਿਆ ਅਉਤਾਰੁ ਲੈ ਸੋ ਪੁਰਖੁ ਸੁਜਾਣੁ ॥

translation.text: You are the Avataar, the Incarnation of the all-knowing Primal Lord.

transliteration.text: autariā autār lai sō purakh sujān .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਝਖੜਿ ਵਾਉ ਨ ਡੋਲਈ ਪਰਬਤੁ ਮੇਰਾਣੁ ॥

translation.text: You are not pushed or shaken by the storm and the wind; you are like the Sumayr Mountain.

transliteration.text: jhakhar vāu n dōlaī parabat mērān .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਜਾਣੈ ਬਿਰਥਾ ਜੀਅ ਕੀ ਜਾਣੀ ਹੂ ਜਾਣੁ ॥

translation.text: You know the inner state of the soul; You are the Knower of knowers.

transliteration.text: jānai birathā jī kī jānī hū jān .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਕਿਆ ਸਾਲਾਹੀ ਸਚੇ ਪਾਤਿਸਾਹ ਜਾਂ ਤੂ ਸੁਘੜੁ ਸੁਜਾਣੁ ॥

translation.text: How can I praise You, O True Supreme King, when You are so wise and all-knowing?

transliteration.text: kiā sālāhī sachē pātisāh jānh tū sughar sujān .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਦਾਨੁ ਜਿ ਸਤਿਗੁਰ ਭਾਵਸੀ ਸੋ ਸਤੇ ਦਾਣੁ ॥

translation.text: Those blessings granted by the Pleasure of the True Guru - please bless Satta with those gifts.

transliteration.text: dān j satigur bhāvasī sō satē dān .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਨਾਨਕ ਹੰਦਾ ਛਤ੍ਰੁ ਸਿਰਿ ਉਮਤਿ ਹੈਰਾਣੁ ॥

translation.text: Seeing Nanak's canopy waving over Your head, everyone was astonished.

transliteration.text: nānak handā shatr sir umat hairān .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਸੋ ਟਿਕਾ ਸੋ ਬੈਹਣਾ ਸੋਈ ਦੀਬਾਣੁ ॥

translation.text: The same mark on the forehead, the same throne, and the same Royal Court.

transliteration.text: sō tikā sō baihanā sōī dībān .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਪਿਯੂ ਦਾਦੇ ਜੇਵਿਹਾ ਪੋਤ੍ਰਾ ਪਰਵਾਣੁ ॥੬॥

translation.text: Just like the father and grandfather, the son is approved. ||6||

transliteration.text: piyū dādē jēvihā pōtrā paravān .6.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਧੰਨੁ ਧੰਨੁ ਰਾਮਦਾਸ ਗੁਰੁ ਜਿਨਿ ਸਿਰਿਆ ਤਿਨੈ ਸਵਾਰਿਆ ॥

translation.text: Blessed, blessed is Guru Raam Daas; He who created You, has also exalted You.

transliteration.text: dhann dhann rāmadās gur jin siriā tinai savāriā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਪੂਰੀ ਹੋਈ ਕਰਾਮਾਤਿ ਆਪਿ ਸਿਰਜਣਹਾਰੈ ਧਾਰਿਆ ॥

translation.text: Perfect is Your miracle; the Creator Lord Himself has installed You on the throne.

transliteration.text: pūrī hōī karāmāt āp sirajanahārai dhāriā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਸਿਖੀ ਅਤੈ ਸੰਗਤੀ ਪਾਰਬ੍ਰਹਮੁ ਕਰਿ ਨਮਸਕਾਰਿਆ ॥

translation.text: The Sikhs and all the Congregation recognize You as the Supreme Lord God, and bow down to You.

transliteration.text: sikhī atai sangatī pārabraham kar namasakāriā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਅਟਲੁ ਅਥਾਹੁ ਅਤੋਲੁ ਤੂ ਤੇਰਾ ਅੰਤੁ ਨ ਪਾਰਾਵਾਰਿਆ ॥

translation.text: You are unchanging, unfathomable and immeasurable; You have no end or limitation.

transliteration.text: atal athāh atōl tū tērā ant n pārāvāriā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਜਿਨ੍ਹੀ ਤੂੰ ਸੇਵਿਆ ਭਾਉ ਕਰਿ ਸੇ ਤੁਧੁ ਪਾਰਿ ਉਤਾਰਿਆ ॥

translation.text: Those who serve You with love - You carry them across.

transliteration.text: jinhī tūn sēviā bhāu kar sē tudh pār utāriā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਲਬੁ ਲੋਭੁ ਕਾਮੁ ਕ੍ਰੋਧੁ ਮੋਹੁ ਮਾਰਿ ਕਢੇ ਤੁਧੁ ਸਪਰਵਾਰਿਆ ॥

translation.text: Greed, envy, sexual desire, anger and emotional attachment - You have beaten them and driven them out.

transliteration.text: lab lōbh kām krōdh mōh mār kadhē tudh saparavāriā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਧੰਨੁ ਸੁ ਤੇਰਾ ਥਾਨੁ ਹੈ ਸਚੁ ਤੇਰਾ ਪੈਸਕਾਰਿਆ ॥

translation.text: Blessed is Your place, and True is Your magnificent glory.

transliteration.text: dhann s tērā thān hai sach tērā paisakāriā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਨਾਨਕੁ ਤੂ ਲਹਣਾ ਤੂਹੈ ਗੁਰੁ ਅਮਰੁ ਤੂ ਵੀਚਾਰਿਆ ॥

translation.text: You are Nanak, You are Angad, and You are Amar Daas; so do I recognize You.

transliteration.text: nānak tū lahanā tūhai gur amar tū vīchāriā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਗੁਰੁ ਡਿਠਾ ਤਾਂ ਮਨੁ ਸਾਧਾਰਿਆ ॥੭॥

translation.text: When I saw the Guru, then my mind was comforted and consoled. ||7||

transliteration.text: gur dithā tānh man sādhāriā .7.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਚਾਰੇ ਜਾਗੇ ਚਹੁ ਜੁਗੀ ਪੰਚਾਇਣੁ ਆਪੇ ਹੋਆ ॥

translation.text: The four Gurus enlightened the four ages; the Lord Himself assumed the fifth form.

transliteration.text: chārē jāgē chah jugī panchāin āpē hōā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਆਪੀਨ੍ਹੈ ਆਪੁ ਸਾਜਿਓਨੁ ਆਪੇ ਹੀ ਥੰਮ੍ਹਿ ਖਲੋਆ ॥

translation.text: He created Himself, and He Himself is the supporting pillar.

transliteration.text: āpīnhai āp sājiōn āpē hī thanmh khalōā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਆਪੇ ਪਟੀ ਕਲਮ ਆਪਿ ਆਪਿ ਲਿਖਣਹਾਰਾ ਹੋਆ ॥

translation.text: He Himself is the paper, He Himself is the pen, and He Himself is the writer.

transliteration.text: āpē patī kalam āp āp likhanahārā hōā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਸਭ ਉਮਤਿ ਆਵਣ ਜਾਵਣੀ ਆਪੇ ਹੀ ਨਵਾ ਨਿਰੋਆ ॥

translation.text: All His followers come and go; He alone is fresh and new.

transliteration.text: sabh umat āvan jāvanī āpē hī navā nirōā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਤਖਤਿ ਬੈਠਾ ਅਰਜਨ ਗੁਰੂ ਸਤਿਗੁਰ ਕਾ ਖਿਵੈ ਚੰਦੋਆ ॥

translation.text: Guru Arjun sits on the throne; the royal canopy waves over the True Guru.

transliteration.text: takhat baithā arajan gurū satigur kā khivai chandōā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਉਗਵਣਹੁ ਤੈ ਆਥਵਣਹੁ ਚਹੁ ਚਕੀ ਕੀਅਨੁ ਲੋਆ ॥

translation.text: From east to west, He illuminates the four directions.

transliteration.text: ugavanah tai āthavanah chah chakī kīan lōā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਜਿਨ੍ਹੀ ਗੁਰੂ ਨ ਸੇਵਿਓ ਮਨਮੁਖਾ ਪਇਆ ਮੋਆ ॥

translation.text: Those self-willed manmukhs who do not serve the Guru die in shame.

transliteration.text: jinhī gurū n sēviō manamukhā paiā mōā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਦੂਣੀ ਚਉਣੀ ਕਰਾਮਾਤਿ ਸਚੇ ਕਾ ਸਚਾ ਢੋਆ ॥

translation.text: Your miracles increase two-fold, even four-fold; this is the True Lord's true blessing.

transliteration.text: dūnī chaunī karāmāt sachē kā sachā dhōā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Bhai Balwand and Satta
author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਚਾਰੇ ਜਾਗੇ ਚਹੁ ਜੁਗੀ ਪੰਚਾਇਣੁ ਆਪੇ ਹੋਆ ॥੮॥੧॥

translation.text: The four Gurus enlightened the four ages; the Lord Himself assumed the fifth form. ||8||1||

transliteration.text: chārē jāgē chah jugī panchāin āpē hōā .8.1.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.description: Bhai Balwand and Satta [15th - 16th Century], were brothers and Rebab players who played music for Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, primarily in the Indian classical melody of Ramkali. Bhai Balwand, also known as Rai Balvand, was by birth a Mirasi, part of a community of genealogists for families in Northern India and Pakistan.

text: ਰਾਮਕਲੀ ਬਾਣੀ ਭਗਤਾ ਕੀ ॥
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Raamkalee, The Word Of The Devotees.

transliteration.text: rāmakalī bānī bhagatā kī .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

text: ਕਬੀਰ ਜੀਉ
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Kabeer Jee:

transliteration.text: kabīr jīu

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

text: ੴ ਸਤਿਗੁਰ ਪ੍ਰਸਾਦਿ ॥
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: One Universal Creator God. By The Grace Of The True Guru:

transliteration.text: ik ōunkār satigur prasād .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

text: ਕਾਇਆ ਕਲਾਲਨਿ ਲਾਹਨਿ ਮੇਲਉ ਗੁਰ ਕਾ ਸਬਦੁ ਗੁੜੁ ਕੀਨੁ ਰੇ ॥
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Make your body the vat, and mix in the yeast. Let the Word of the Guru's Shabad be the molasses.

transliteration.text: kāiā kalālan lāhan mēlau gur kā sabad gur kīn rē .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.
